sen.j: 醍醐寺（だいごじ）は、京都府京都市伏見区醍醐東大路町にある真言宗醍醐派総本山の寺院。
sen.e: Daigo-ji is a Shingon Buddhist temple of the Daigo-ha branch, in Daigo Higashioji, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto.
Daigo-ji Temple is a head temple of the Daigo-ha branch of Shingon Buddhism, in Daigo Higashioji, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Daigo-ji→Daigo-ji Temple 総本山→head templeが抜けていたので補足。 京都府京都市の英訳を補足。
sen.e: Daigo-ji Temple is a head temple of the Daigo-ha branch of Shingon Buddhism, in Daigo Higashioji, Fushimi Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 山号を醍醐山（深雪山とも）と称する。
sen.e: It is also called Mt. Daigo (or Mt. Miyuki).
It is also called Mt. Daigo (or Mt. Miyuki).
It is also called Mt. Daigo (or Mt. Miyuki).

sen.j: 本尊は薬師如来、開基（創立者）は理源大師聖宝（しょうぼう）である。
sen.e: It venerates Yakushi, and was founded by Rigen-daishi Shobo.
It venerates Yakushi, and was founded by Rigen-daishi Shobo.
It venerates Yakushi, and was founded by Rigen-daishi Shobo.

sen.j: 古都京都の文化財の一部として世界遺産に登録されている。
sen.e: As a part of the Old Town Kyoto Cultural Property, it is a registered World Heritage Site.
As part of the Cultural Assets of Ancient City Kyoto, it is registered with a World Heritage Site.
sen.cmt: 文章を自然な表現に修正。Old Town→Ancient City
sen.e: As a part of the Cultural Assets of Ancient City Kyoto, it is a registered World Heritage Site.

sen.j: 伏見区東方に広がる醍醐山（笠取山）に200万坪以上の広大な境内をもつ寺院である。
sen.e: The temple has extensive grounds of over 2million tsubo on Mt. Daigo (Mt. Kasatori) in the east side of Fushimi Ward.
The temple has extensive grounds of over 2 million tsubos on Mt. Daigo (Mt. Kasatori) in the east side of Fushimi Ward.
sen.cmt: a tsubo=about 3.3㎡ 坪は日本の土地面積の単位なので、tsuboと表記されたのだと思いますが、ここだけイタリックにする必要があるかどうか、判断の方をお願いします。なお、2の前にスペースを空けました。
sen.e: The temple has extensive grounds of over 6.6 million sq.m. on Mt. Daigo (Mt. Kasatori) in the east side of Fushimi Ward.

sen.j: 豊臣秀吉による「醍醐の花見」の行われた地としても知られる。
sen.e: It is known as the place where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's "Daigo Flower Viewing" was held.
It is known as the place where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's "Daigo Flower Viewing" was held.
It is known as the place where Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's "Daigo Flower Viewing" was held.

sen.j: 醍醐寺の創建は貞観_(日本)16年（874年）、空海の孫弟子にあたる理源大師聖宝が准胝観音（じゅんていかんのん）並びに如意輪観音を笠取山頂上に迎えて開山、聖宝は同山頂付近を「醍醐山」と名付けた。
sen.e: Daigo-ji Temple was built in Jogan 16 (874 AD), when Rigen-daishi Shobo, a 2nd generation disciple of Kukai, placed Juntei Kannon and Nyoirin Kannon on top of Mt. Kasatori and named the area around the peak "Mt. Daigo".

Daigo-ji Temple was built in Jogan 16 (874 AD), when Rigen-daishi Shobo, a 2nd generation disciple of Kukai, placed Juntei Kannon and Nyoirin Kannon on top of Mt. Kasatori and named the area around the peak "Mt. Daigo".

Daigo-ji Temple was built in 874, when Rigen-daishi Shobo, a 2nd generation disciple of Kukai, placed Juntei Kannon and Nyoirin Kannon on top of Mt. Kasatori and named the area around the peak "Mt. Daigo".

sen.j: 醍醐寺は山深い醍醐山頂上一帯を中心に、多くの修験者の霊場として発展した後（この場所を「上醍醐」と呼称する）、醍醐天皇は醍醐寺を自らの祈願寺とすると共に手厚い庇護を掛け、その圧倒的な財力によって醍醐山麓の広大な平地に大伽藍「下醍醐」が発展することになる。
sen.e: Deep in the mountains and centered around around the peak of Mt. Daigo (this area is called "Upper Daigo"), at first Daigo-ji Temple developed as a sacred site for ascetics, later growing into a large monastery ("Lower Daigo") on the broad, flat land at the foot of Mt. Daigo thanks to the overwhelming support of Emperor Daigo, who decided to make it his place for prayer.

Deep in the mountains and centered around the peak of Mt. Daigo (this area is called "Upper Daigo"), at first Daigo-ji Temple developed as a sacred site for ascetics, later growing into Daigaran (large monastery), "Lower Daigo", on the broad, flat land at the foot of Mt. Daigo thanks to the overwhelming support of Emperor Daigo, who decided to make it his place for prayer.
sen.cmt: around around→around 伽藍→a cathedral, a big Buddhist temple ともあり。 大伽藍の日本語読みを補足。
sen.e: Deep in the mountains and centered around the peak of Mt. Daigo (this area is called "Upper Daigo"), at first Daigo-ji Temple developed as a sacred site for ascetics, later growing into Daigaran (large monastery), "Lower Daigo", on the broad, flat land at the foot of Mt. Daigo thanks to the overwhelming support of Emperor Daigo, who decided to make it his place for prayer.

sen.j: その後応仁の乱など相次ぐ戦争で下醍醐は荒廃し、五重塔しか残らないありさまであった。
sen.e: Later on Lower Daigo was ruined in the Onin war and many other battles, leaving only the 5 story pagoda.
Later on Lower Daigo was ruined in the Onin war and many other battles, leaving only the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda).
sen.cmt: 下記、絵画の欄でGoju-no-toとあるので、統一する為に修正。
sen.e: Later on Lower Daigo was ruined in the Onin war and many other battles, leaving only the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda).

sen.j: しかし豊臣秀吉による「醍醐の花見」をきっかけに紀州などからの寺院建築の移築や三宝院の建設などにより今日見るような姿となっている。
sen.e: However, thanks to the relocation of temple buildings from Kishu and construction of the Sanboin for Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Daigo Flower Viewing, it has taken on the appearance we see today.
However, thanks to the relocation of temple buildings from Kishu and construction of Sanboin for Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Daigo Flower Viewing, it has taken on the appearance we see today.
sen.cmt: 三宝院 (醍醐寺の院家）は固有名詞なので、theを削除。
sen.e: However, thanks to the relocation of temple buildings from Kishu and construction of Sanboin for Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Daigo Flower Viewing, it has taken on the appearance we see today.

sen.j: 1939年夏、上醍醐を襲った山火事で短時間の間に、経蔵など点在する建築が焼失した。
sen.e: In the summer of 1939, the scripture repository and other isolated buildings were all lost during a short period due to a wildfire that struck Upper Daigo.
In the summer of 1939, the Kyozo (scripture repository) and other isolated buildings were all lost during a short period due to a wildfire that struck Upper Daigo.
sen.cmt: 経蔵の日本語読みを補足、英訳を大文字に修正。
sen.e: In the summer of 1939, the Kyozo (scripture repository) and other isolated buildings were all lost during a short period due to a wildfire that struck Upper Daigo.

sen.j: 1995年1月17日に発生した兵庫県南部地震の影響で、五重塔と金堂の漆喰がはがれた。
sen.e: Some plaster fell off of the 5 story pagoda and the main hall in the Kobe Earthquake on January 17, 1995.
Some plaster of the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) and the Kondo (main hall) fell off in the Kobe Earthquake on January 17, 1995.
sen.cmt: ofからhallまでをsome plasterの後に移動。 日本語読みのKondoを補足。 Goju-no-toを補足。
sen.e: Some plaster of the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) and the Kondo (main hall) fell off in the Kobe Earthquake on January 17, 1995.

tit.cmt: 伽藍は仏教独特の言葉なので、日本語読みを補足。

sen.j: 上醍醐と下醍醐は険しい山道で隔てられ、徒歩で1時間は要する。
sen.e: Upper and Lower Daigo are separated by a steep mountain path, requiring about an hour to walk between them.
Upper and Lower Daigo are separated by a steep mountain path, requiring about an hour to walk between them.
Upper and Lower Daigo are separated by a steep mountain path, requiring about an hour to walk between them.

sen.j: 本尊薬師如来を安置する「金堂」、「三宝院」などを中心に、上醍醐とは対照的な絢爛な大伽藍が広がる。
sen.e: Centered around the Main Hall and Sanboin, where Yakushi Nyorai statues are installed, the magnificent monastery contrasts with Upper Daigo.
Centered around the Kondo (main hall) and Sanboin, where Yakushi Nyorai statues are installed, the magnificent Daigaran (monastery) contrasts with Upper Daigo.
sen.cmt: 日本語読みのKondo, Daigaranを補足。
sen.e: Centered around the Kondo (main hall) and Sanboin, where Yakushi Nyorai statues are installed, the magnificent Daigaran (monastery) contrasts with Upper Daigo.

sen.j: しかし壮大な下醍醐の伽藍は応仁の乱によってほぼ全焼し、その後も幾度の火災によって焼失・再建を繰り返しているが、護摩道場前に建つ五重塔は奇跡的に創建当時のまま現在に残る。
sen.e: However, Lower Daigo's splendid monastery burned down in the Onin War, and has since been burned and rebuilt several more times; but the 5-story Pagoda miraculously stands in front of the Goma-dojo today just as it did when it was first built.

However, Lower Daigo's splendid Garan (monastery) burned down in the Onin War, and has since been burned and rebuilt several more times; but the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) miraculously stands in front of the Goma-dojo today just as it did when it was first built.
sen.cmt: 日本語読みのGaranを補足。 Goju-no-toを補足。
sen.e: However, Lower Daigo's splendid Garan (monastery) burned down in the Onin War, and has since been burned and rebuilt several more times; but the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) miraculously stands in front of the Goma-dojo today just as it did when it was first built.

sen.j: また五重塔内部に描かれた壁画も国宝に指定されており、中でも空海の肖像画は同人を描いた現存する最古のものである。
sen.e: The paintings on the inside walls of the pagoda are designated National Treasures; and the portraits of Kukai are the oldest extant paintings of him.
The paintings on the inside walls of the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) are designated National Treasures; and the portrait of Kukai is the oldest extant painting of him.
sen.cmt: 空海の最古の肖像画は単数だと思われるので、文章後半を単数形に修正。www.daigoji.or.jp/e/vihara/down/down10.html に以下の文章あり。Especially the figure of Kukai is the oldest among the extant drawings and paintings. Goju-no-toを補足。
sen.e: The paintings on the inside walls of the Goju-no-to (5-story pagoda) are designated National Treasures; and the portrait of Kukai is the oldest extant painting of him.

sen.j: 西大門
sen.e: Saidai-Mon Gate
Saidai-Mon Gate

sen.j: 金堂（国宝） - 現在の建物は豊臣秀吉の発願により紀州湯浅の（12世紀後半に建立された後白河法皇の御願寺）本堂を慶長4年（1599年）に移築・再建。
sen.e: Main Hall (National Treasure) – The current building was the main hall from Kishu Yuasa (a temple built for the Monk-Emperor Go-Shirakawa in the latter half of the 12th century), which was moved and rebuilt in Keicho 4 (1599), at the request of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

Kondo (Main hall, National Treasure) -The current building was the main hall from Kishu Yuasa (a temple built for the Monk-Emperor Go-Shirakawa in the latter half of the 12th century), which was moved and rebuilt in Keicho 4 (1599), at the request of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

Kondo (Main hall, National Treasure) -The current building was the main hall from Kishu Yuasa (a temple built for the Monk-Emperor Go-Shirakawa in the latter half of the 12th century), which was moved and rebuilt in 1599, at the request of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI.

sen.j: 五重塔（国宝） - 天暦5年（951年）に醍醐天皇の冥福を祈るために朱雀天皇が建立したもので、醍醐寺のなかでも唯一の創建当時からの建物。
sen.e: 5-Story Pagoda (National Treasure) – Built by Emperor Suzaku in Tenryaku 5 (951) to pray for the happiness of departed Emperor Daigo, it is the only original building left at Daigo-ji Temple.

Goju-no-to (5-Story Pagoda, National Treasure) _ Built by Emperor Suzaku in Tenryaku 5 (951) to pray for the happiness of departed Emperor Daigo, it is the only original building left at Daigo-ji Temple.

Goju-no-to (5-Story Pagoda, National Treasure) _ Built by Emperor Suzaku in Tenryaku 5 (951) to pray for the happiness of departed Emperor Daigo, it is the only original building left at Daigo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 清龍宮本殿（重要文化財） - 慶長4年（1599年）建立。
sen.e: Seiryu-gu Main Hall (Important Cultural Property) – Built in Keicho 4 (1599)
Seiryu-gu Main Hall (Important Cultural Property) – Built in Keicho 4 (1599)
Seiryu-gu Main Hall (Important Cultural Property) – Built in Keicho 4 (1599)

sen.j: 弁天堂 - 昭和5年（1930年）に林泉の北東岸に建立された建物。
sen.e: Bentendo - Built on the northeast coast of Rinsen in Showa 5 (1930)
Bentendo - Built on the northeast coast of Rinsen in Showa 5 (1930)
Bentendo - Built on the northeast coast of Rinsen in Showa 5 (1930)

sen.j: 大講堂 - 昭和5年（1930年）建立。
sen.e: Auditorium – Built in Showa 5 (1930)
Auditorium – Built in Showa 5 (1930)

sen.j: 女人堂
sen.e: Women's Temple
Nyonindo (Women's Temple)
sen.cmt: 醍醐寺の公式サイト (英語)には、Nyonindoとある。
sen.e: Nyonindo (Women's Temple)

sen.j: 西国三十三箇所第11番札所であり、西国一険しい札所として知られる。
sen.e: The 11th temple of the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage, it is known as the steepest one in Saigoku.
The 11th temple of the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage, it is known as the steepest one in Saigoku.
The 11th temple of the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage, it is known as the steepest one in Saigoku.

sen.j: 上り口にはかつて女人結界があったことから、女人堂がおかれ、そこから険しい山あいに、平安時代のままに残る国宝の薬師堂、醍醐寺の鎮守神である清瀧権現（せいりゅうごんげん）拝殿（国宝）、准胝堂、五大堂などが立ち並ぶ。
sen.e: Because the temple used to be off limits to women, a Women's Temple was placed at the bottom of the path; starting there, the Yakushido (a National Treasure, and still as it was in the Heian period), the worship hall (National Treasure) for Daigo-ji's guardian deity Seiryugongen, the Junteido, and Godaido are lined up on the steep mountain.

Because the temple used to be off limits to women, the Nyonindo (women's temple) was placed at the bottom of the path; starting there, the Yakushido (a National Treasure, and still as it was in the Heian period), the Haiden (worship hall, National Treasure) for Daigo-ji's guardian deity Seiryu-gongen, the Junteido and the Godaido are lined up on the steep mountain.
sen.cmt: Nyonindo日本語読みを補足。 拝殿: Haidenは日本語読みも記載されている事が多いので補足。 Seiryugongen→Seiryu-gongen
sen.e: Because the temple used to be off limits to women, the Nyonindo (women's temple) was placed at the bottom of the path; starting there, the Yakushido (a National Treasure, and still as it was in the Heian period), the Haiden (worship hall, National Treasure) for Daigo-ji's guardian deity Seiryu-gongen, the Junteido and the Godaido are lined up on the steep mountain.

sen.j: 上醍醐には有名な「醍醐水」が今も湧き出ているほか、醍醐山頂（標高450m）には、如意輪堂（重文）と開山堂（重文）と白山大権現が並ぶ。
sen.e: In addition to the famous Daigo Water that still springs forth on Upper Daigo, Nyoirindo (Important Cultural Property), Kaisando (Important Cultural Property), and Hakusan Daigongen are to be found on the peak of Mt. Daigo (altitude 450m).

In addition to the famous Daigo Water that still springs forth on Upper Daigo, the Nyoirindo (Important Cultural Property), the Kaisando (Important Cultural Property) and the Hakusan Daigongen are to be found on the peak of Mt. Daigo (altitude 450m).

In addition to the famous Daigo Water that still springs forth on Upper Daigo, the Nyoirindo (Important Cultural Property), the Kaisando (Important Cultural Property) and the Hakusan Daigongen are to be found on the peak of Mt. Daigo (altitude 450m).

sen.j: 山頂から笠取山に向かう途中に奥の院がある。
sen.e: An inner sanctum is situated between the peak and Mt. Kasatori.
The Oku-no-in (inner sanctum) is situated between the peak and Mt. Kasatori.
sen.cmt: Oku-no in日本語読みを補足。各サイトで日本語読みの記載率が高い。
sen.e: The Oku-no-in (inner sanctum) is situated between the peak and Mt. Kasatori.

sen.j: 清滝宮拝殿（国宝） - 永享6年（1434年）に再建、清滝宮は弘法大師（空海）が唐・長安の青龍寺から勧請した密教の守護神を祀った醍醐寺の鎮守社。
sen.e: Seiryu-gu Worship Hall (National Treasure) – Rebuilt in Eikyo 6 (1434), Seiryu-gu is a shrine to a guardian deity of esoteric Buddhism which Kobo-daishi (Kukai) brought from Qinglong Temple in Chang-an, Tang China.

Seiryu-gu Haiden (Worship Hall, National Treasure) - Rebuilt in Eikyo 6 (1434), Seiryu-gu is a shrine to a guardian deity of esoteric Buddhism which Kobo-daishi (Kukai) brought from Qinglong Temple in Chang-an, Tang China.
sen.cmt: Haiden日本語読みを補足。清龍宮/清滝宮→同義と思われる。
sen.e: Seiryu-gu Haiden (Worship Hall, National Treasure) - Rebuilt in Eikyo 6 (1434), Seiryu-gu is a shrine to a guardian deity of esoteric Buddhism which Kobo-daishi (Kukai) brought from Qinglong Temple in Chang-an, Tang China.

sen.j: 薬師堂（国宝） - 保安 (元号)2年（1121年）から5年をかけて再建、醍醐天皇の御願により延喜7年（907年）頃に理源大師（聖宝）により建立。
sen.e: Yakushido (National Treasure) – Rebuilt over 5 years beginning in Hoan 2 (1121), it was first built by Rigen-daishi (Shobo) around Engi 7 (907) at the request of Emperor Daigo.
Yakushido (National Treasure) – Rebuilt over 5 years beginning in Hoan 2 (1121), it was first built by Rigen-daishi (Shobo) around Engi 7 (907) at the request of Emperor Daigo.
Yakushido (National Treasure) – Rebuilt over 5 years beginning in Hoan 2 (1121), it was first built by Rigen-daishi (Shobo) around Engi 7 (907) at the request of Emperor Daigo.

sen.j: 醍醐水 － 聖宝が感得し、醍醐寺の名前の由来となったといわれる霊泉。
sen.e: Daigo Water - This sacred spring is said to have been the source of the name of Daigo-ji, after Shobo had an epiphany there.
Daigo Water - This sacred spring is said to have been the source of the name of Daigo-ji Temple, after Shobo had an epiphany there.
Daigo Water - This sacred spring is said to have been the source of the name of Daigo-ji Temple, after Shobo had an epiphany there.

sen.j: 准胝堂 － 聖宝が如意輪堂とともに建立、西国三十三箇所第十一番札所。
sen.e: Junteido – Built by Shobo along with the Nyoirindo, it is the 11th temple in the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage.
sen.cmt: 一行目と二行目の行間が他と違いますが、そのままにしています。
sen.e: Junteido – Built by Shobo along with the Nyoirindo, it is the 11th temple in the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage.
Junteido – Built by Shobo along with the Nyoirindo, it is the 11th temple in the Saigoku 33 Kannon Pilgrimage.

sen.j: 五大堂 － 聖宝が開いた国家鎮護の祈願道場。
sen.e: Godaido – Opened by Shobo as a place to pray for the protection of the nation.
Godaido – Opened by Shobo as a place to pray for the protection of the nation.
Godaido – Opened by Shobo as a place to pray for the protection of the nation.

sen.j: 如意輪堂（上醍醐） - 慶長11年（1606年）に豊臣秀頼により再建、理源大師（聖宝）により准胝堂とともに建立されたと伝わる
sen.e: Nyoirindo (Upper Daigo) – Rebuilt by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), its construction is attributed to Rigen-daishi (Shobo), the same as Junteido.
Nyoirindo (Upper Daigo) _ Rebuilt by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), its construction is attributed to Rigen-daishi (Shobo), the same as the Junteido.
Nyoirindo (Upper Daigo) _ Rebuilt by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), its construction is attributed to Rigen-daishi (Shobo), the same as the Junteido.

sen.j: 開山堂（上醍醐） - 如意輪堂ともに慶長11年（1606年）に豊臣秀頼により再建、内陣の厨子には理源大師（聖宝）坐像など安置
sen.e: Kaisando (Upper Daigo) – Rebuilt along with Nyoirindo by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), a statue of a seated Rigen-daishi (Shobo) is installed in a box-shrine in its sanctuary.
Kaisando (Upper Daigo) _ Rebuilt along with the Nyoirindo by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), a seated statue of Rigen-daishi (Shobo) is installed in Zushi (miniature shrine) in its sanctuary.
sen.cmt: theを補足。 a statue of a seated→a seated statue of 厨子→miniature shrine, shrine box, small shrine 日本語読みを補足。
sen.e: Kaisando (Upper Daigo) _ Rebuilt along with the Nyoirindo by Hideyori TOYOTOMI in Keicho 11 (1606), a seated statue of Rigen-daishi (Shobo) is installed in Zushi (miniature shrine) in its sanctuary.

sen.j: 醍醐寺の主な行事としては、醍醐派が本家である壮大な屋外大護摩柴燈護摩（さいとうごま）を中心とした施餓鬼法要が8月に厳修されるほか、2月には同様に柴燈護摩を炊き上げて五大明王の功徳を讚える「五大力尊仁王会」（ごだいりきそんにんのうえ）が厳修され併せて150キロ近い巨大な鏡餅を持ち上げる力比べが行われることで有名。
sen.e: One of Daigo Temple's major activities is the Segekai memorial service, which centers around the magnificent outdoor bonfire Saito-Goma, originated by the Daigo branch, held in August; in February at the Godairikison Ninnoe festival the temple burns the same Saito-Goma bonfire and tells the story of the pious deeds of the Godai Myoo; that festival is famous the contest of strength, in which participants lift a giant rice cake of nearly 150kg.

One of Daigo-ji Temple's major activities is the Segaki memorial service, which centers around the magnificent outdoor bonfire Saito-Goma, originated by the Daigo-ha branch, held in August; in February at the Godairikison Ninnoe festival the temple burns the same Saito-Goma bonfire and praise the virtuous deeds of the Godai Myoo; that festival is famous for the contest of strength, in which participants lift a giant Kagami mochi (rice cake) of nearly 150kg.
sen.cmt: Daigo→Daigo-ji Segekai→Segaki Daigo branch→Daigo-ha branch 功徳: 徳の高い行い、 神の恵みの事なのでpious→virtuousの方がより良いかと思われる。 讃える、なのでtells the story of→praise famous→famous for Kagami mochi (鏡餅), literally mirror rice cake, is a traditional Japanese New Year decoration. 日本語読みを補足。
sen.e: One of Daigo-ji Temple's major activities is the Segaki memorial service, which centers around the magnificent outdoor bonfire Saito-Goma, originated by the Daigo-ha sect, held in August; in February at the Godairikison Ninnoe festival the temple burns the same Saito-Goma bonfire and praise the virtuous deeds of the Godai Myoo; that festival is famous for the contest of strength, in which participants lift a giant Kagami mochi (rice cake) of nearly 150kg.

sen.j: また4月には豊臣秀吉の「醍醐の花見」にちなんで現在も全山を揚げての花見会が開催される。
sen.e: Also in April, the whole mountain is opened up for cherry blossom viewing, in honor of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Daigo Flower Viewing.
Also in April, the whole mountain is opened up for cherry blossom viewing, in honor of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI's Daigo Flower Viewing.
